5 Actually Useful CSS & HTML tools

08 Jul 2011

1. Fillerati
You have to admit that reading “Lorem Ipsum” over and over gets boring. Fillerati solves that problem by selecting random passages from literary classics like Carroll’s  Alice in Wonderland. This tool even takes it a step further by even generating HTML tags to go with it like lists, headings, and paragraphs.
» http://www.fillerati.com/

2. CSS3 Generator
Want to generate css text-shadows in about 10 seconds? Howabout at the same time see which browsers the generated code is compatible with? It even offers you a nice preview area.
» http://css3generator.com/

3. Code Beautifier
CodeBeautifier optimizes and cleans up your css code. Once you’ve written your stylesheet pop it into the beautifier and choose between several options like a balance between readability and size, hardcore smallest size possible, or according to custom settings that you pick.
» http://www.codebeautifier.com/

4. PXtoEM
“[...] text set in EMs scale to the body font-size. Only one element’s font-size needs to change instead of individually changing the font-size of each element. [...] Accessibility is increased for end-users because text is scaled based on their preferences rather than set statically in pixels.” Keeping track of EMs can be a difficult task since it can vary depending on the body font size you choose. Thankfully PXtoEM provides handy conversion tables and converters to keep you from getting a headache.
» http://pxtoem.com

5. FontSquirrel’s @Font-Face Generator
Who doesn’t like fancy fonts on their website? Stick a compatible font file from your computer into the generator and FontSquirrel will automatically convert then spit out code + files for you to use. It’s highly supported by a growing community and extremely up to date with changing standards.
» http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fontface/generator
